dt: {bc}to produce by or as if by incubation {bc}{sx|hatch||}

dt.t: I used to {wi}brood{/wi} these things on my walk
the old fort {wi}brooding{/wi} above the valley

dt: {bc}to be in a state of depression

et: Middle English {it}broden{/it}, verbal derivative of {it}brod, brood{/it} {et_link|brood:1|brood:1}
shortdef: to produce by or as if by incubation : hatch

dt: {bc}the young of an animal or a family of young
{bc}the young (as of a bird or insect) hatched or cared for at one time

dt.t: a hen with her {wi}brood{/wi} of chicks

dt: {bc}a group having a common nature or origin

dt.t: takes their {wi}brood{/wi} to church every Sunday

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}brōd{/it}; akin to Middle High German {it}bruot{/it} brood and perhaps to Old English {it}beorma{/it} yeast {ma}{mat|barm|}{/ma}
shortdef: the young of an animal or a family of young; especially : the young (as of a bird or insect) hatched or cared for at one time
a group having a common nature or origin
